title: ESP Program Manager Seeks Balance Between Joy, Hard Moments
text:
Katie Barlow is the Athens program manager of Extra Special People (ESP), an organization that supports disabled people by promoting inclusivity through its events and services.
Q: How did you get involved with ESP?
I didn‚Äôt have experience with ESP beforehand; I was one of the first people at ESP to be hired as a complete outsider onto the full-time team. They‚Äôve done that a couple of times. But typically, the best way to get a full-time job at ESP is to volunteer.
Essentially, whenever I moved to Athens, I was looking for ways to be involved with my recreational therapy license, outside of behavioral health, because although I love behavioral health, it was just a really heavy topic.
Q: What has been the most rewarding experience in your time with ESP?
I think it‚Äôs really cool just to see the impact of that community (ESP), not only for myself, but also for our families who have never had a place of belonging before. Like, they‚Äôre outsiders in the rest of the community, but when they come here, they fit right in, and they know that there‚Äôs always gonna be someone here to care about them and be there for them.
Q: What has been your biggest obstacle in this role?
I think within the mission of ESP, it‚Äôs such a beautiful mission. And it‚Äôs so light hearted and filled with so much joy, that it can be easy to forget that there‚Äôs a lot of hard moments that come with that too. With our population, there are sometimes things that can happen that are really sad and heartbreaking.
Q: What would you say is one of ESP‚Äôs biggest accomplishments?
I think our ability to provide wraparound services for our family. So we‚Äôre not just like, you come here and have fun, and then we send you home. Like we truly care about you as family. We care about our participants as individuals, and we‚Äôre going to do whatever we can to provide support for them, no matter what they‚Äôre going through. And I think that‚Äôs a huge one.
Q: What is the Java Joy program through ESP and what does it entail?
Java Joy is our adult employment opportunity. It‚Äôs a way to provide inclusive employment for adults with disabilities, and we do that through a mobile coffee cart.
It‚Äôs really cool because we get to take our ‚Äújoyristas‚Äù are what we call them, it‚Äôs a mixture between joy and then baristas, into the community and we get to (A.) give them employment experience and then (B.) provide experience to interact with people with disabilities within the community. And so it‚Äôs a really cool way for other organizations to employ adults with disabilities without directly hiring them onto their staff.
Q: If you could tell someone one thing about ESP, what would it be?
I would say that ESP isn‚Äôt just inclusive for our participants, it‚Äôs inclusive for everyone who walks through our doors. Whether that‚Äôs a family member, a community member, a donor, a volunteer, our staff. We want it to be a place where everyone feels welcome.

Liza Adamik is a public relations major covering diversity and equity.

text:
Delta Pilot Demands Black Passenger Remove Hat Or 'Leave The Airplane' In Resurfaced Video A video of a Delta Air Lines pilot berating and belittling a Black woman as he demanded she remove the hat on her head has resurfaced online.
Natasha Decker ‚Ä¢ Aug 8, 2024
Photo Credit: Forsaken Films / Unsplash A video of a Delta Air Lines pilot berating and belittling a Black woman as he demanded she remove the hat on her head has resurfaced online.
The video first made waves in 2020. It captures a white male pilot standing in an aircraft‚Äôs aisle and arguing with a seated passenger, the Black woman. The clip initially recorded their dispute over the woman‚Äôs hat, which said ‚Äúf**k.‚Äù
The pilot said the woman needed to remove her hat, and she asked for evidence from Delta‚Äôs guidelines that her cap was unacceptable. The two went back and forth as the captain demanded that the Black woman concede to him despite her already taking off the hat. As the captain continued, he insisted that the woman promise to keep the hat off for the rest of the flight or risk being deplaned .
‚ÄúI‚Äôm the captain of the airplane, that‚Äôs where it‚Äôs posted,‚Äù he clapped back at the woman‚Äôs request for where she could find a relevant Delta rule about her hat. ‚ÄúDelta has guidelines, and I don‚Äôt have to explain them to you.‚Äù
‚ÄúYou can take it off, or you can leave the airplane. It is inappropriate, and I‚Äôm not gonna take vulgar language on the flight,‚Äù he added.
As things escalated, the woman told the pilot, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt point your finger at us.‚Äù
The pilot continued to pressure the Black woman into agreeing to his terms. He said, ‚ÄúTell me it‚Äôs off for the entire flight. I have six kids, I raised 10 kids‚ÄîI know better.‚Äù
She responded, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a child, sir. The hat is in my lap.‚Äù
A clip of the incident was reposted on August 1 on X. It has garnered over 2.5 million views and received over 1,000 replies.

Around the beginning of the video, the pilot says he requested that flight attendants ask the woman to remove her hat. That was before he came to do it himself.
The Black woman was seemingly the person who recorded the heated interaction with the pilot. Delta tweeted a response to a clip of the incident back in 2020. The carrier noted that it had ‚Äúfollowed up with those directly involved.‚Äù In part, the airline‚Äôs statement said, ‚ÄúDelta does not condone discrimination of a person or group for any reason. As a global carrier with a diverse workforce, serving a diverse customer base, we are committed to treating all passengers equally.‚Äù
The carrier‚Äôs response was to a tweet that identified the pilot as Captain Dennis Reilly.
A contract of carriage is a terms and conditions document between an airline and its passengers. In Delta‚Äôs, underneath the airline‚Äôs reasons for refusal to transport, it includes, ‚ÄúWhen the passenger‚Äôs conduct, attire, hygiene or odor creates an unreasonable risk of offense or annoyance to other passengers.‚Äù
Many of the tweet replies to the resurfaced video shared similar sentiments that the pilot was unnecessarily aggressive. See some of X users‚Äô responses to the clip below.
